docs.lead_paragraph: With her weight dwindling to 95 pounds on her 5-foot-10-inch frame, Kathryn Bromfield decided she needed more than another trip to a hospital psychiatric ward to survive anorexia. Her insurance company, however, would not pay for residential treatment at a center specializing in eating disorders. Ms. Bromfield turned to her parents, who mortgaged their house and used credit cards to pay more than $53,000 for 11 weeks of treatment.

headline.main: Insurers Pushed to Cover Eating Disorders

docs.abstract: Advocates for victims of eating disorders hope lawsuit settled recently in Minnesota will compel insurers across country to pay for treatment for anorexia sufferers; in Minnesota case, Blue Cross and Blue Shield of Minnesota has agreed to $1 million settlement with family of young woman who committed suicide after suffering from anorexia for five years and being denied coverage by Blue Cross (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: For years, the Hartford teachers' union relished its reputation as the most militant in the nation. It got its members the highest teacher salaries despite their students' having the lowest test scores in the state. When a for-profit company was brought in to manage the public schools, the union ran it out of town. When the legislature moved to take over the schools, union leaders planted themselves in the Statehouse singing ''I Could Have Danced All Night,'' determined, as one leader said, that ''no one would see us sweat.''

headline.main: A Tough Union Backs Change; Schools Benefit

docs.abstract: Hartford, Conn, schools have begun turnaround, supported and in some ways led by American Federation of Teachers, teachers union which for years relished reputation as most militant in nation that got teachers highest salary despite students' having lowest test scores in state; have taken center stage in campaign to change union's image, from impediment to leader of reform, as national unions become squeezed by for-profit companies as well as public support for vouchers and charter schools; desire for new image reflects new reality that reform is matter of survival; teachers unions feel if they fail to improve schools someone else will and will kill unions in meantime; graphs; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Representative Charlie Norwood, the Georgia Republican who has been leading a six-year effort to enact a patients' bill of rights, was moving close to an agreement with the White House on compromise legislation that could be put to a vote in the House of Representatives this week, Mr. Norwood's spokesman said tonight. The spokesman, John E. Stone, said: ''We feel that we are within striking distance of a deal -- more so probably than at any time in the past. Whether that deal can be consummated remains to be seen.''

headline.main: Key Lawmaker Is Reported Near Deal With Bush on Rights Bill

docs.abstract: Rep Charlie Norwood, Georgia Republican leading six-year effort to enact patients' bill of rights, is moving close to agreement with White House on compromise legislation that could be put to vote in House within days; compromise could avert embarrassment for Pres Bush, who does not have enough votes to stop patients' bill favored by Norwood and most Democrats in House and Senate (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: You're right. Doctors are angry -- but certainly not at their patients.

docs.lead_paragraph: Millions of parents take it as an article of faith that putting a bicycle helmet on their children, or themselves, will help keep them out of harm's way. But new data on bicycle accidents raises questions about that. The number of head injuries has increased 10 percent since 1991, even as bicycle helmet use has risen sharply, according to figures compiled by the Consumer Product Safety Commission. But given that ridership has declined over the same period, the rate of head injuries per active cyclist has increased 51 percent just as bicycle helmets have become widespread.

headline.main: A Bicycling Mystery: Head Injuries Piling Up

docs.abstract: New data from Consumer Product Safety Commission shows number of head injuries among bicycle riders has increased 10 percent since 1991, in period when bicycle helmet use has risen sharply and ridership has declined; given ridership decline, rate of head injuries per active cyclist has increased 51 percent just as bicycle helmets have become widespread; safety experts say helmets do not prevent accidents from happening, but are extremely effective at reducing severity of head injuries when they do occur; say helmets can reduce severity of brain injuries by as much as 88 percent; experts are mystified as to why injuries are on rise; some cycling advocates contend that rising numbers of aggressive drivers are at fault; others suggest that many riders wear helmets improperly; specialists in risk analysis say riders using helmets may feel inflated sense of security and take more risks; photos; chart (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: Lynn Elizabeth Thacher, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles G. Thacher of Chappaqua, N.Y., was married on Block Island yesterday to Tobias Alexander Dengel, a son of Dr. Gisela A. Dengel and Dr. Ottmar H. Dengel of Front Royal, Va. The Rev. James R. Pearce, an American Baptist minister, officiated at the Spring House Hotel in the town of New Shoreham, R.I. Mrs. Dengel, 25, is a candidate for a master's degree in mother and child health from the Center for International Child Health of University College, London. Next month she is to become a student at the Georgetown University Medical School in Washington. The bride graduated from Dartmouth College. Her father is an executive vice president and an actuarial consultant at USI Insurance Services in New York and is the chairman of Workshop in Business Opportunities, a New York organization that provides entrepreneurial training in minority communities. Her mother, Ann H. Thacher, who is retired, taught mathematics at the Rippowam-Cisqua School, a private middle school in Bedford, N.Y.

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Of course we must be concerned about people in other countries who are ill (front page, July 23). But there is something wrong when our best facilities are blind to the 43 million uninsured Americans, and the millions in health maintenance organizations who are subject to limited care and bureaucratic regulations that can prevent a patient in one state from getting treatment in another.
docs.abstract: Meyer Rangell letter wonders at American hospitals that treat foreigners when there are 43 million uninsured Americans (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: A MODEST proposal: give every American an M.R.I. as part of a yearly checkup. The scans will surely catch disease at an early stage for a few, and they won't harm anyone. True, they may cost a few thousand dollars per person, but in America cost is not allowed to affect medical decisions. Indeed, the subject of cost is taboo, even in the face of the threat that health-care premiums will rise beyond the reach of millions of poor and low-income families. Recently, Blue Cross of California announced that it would begin paying bonuses to doctors whose patients give them high marks. It is, of course, good news when managed-care plans try to improve the quality of health care. But what if getting ''high marks'' simply means lavishing inappropriate care on patients? And how can it not mean that when the nation lacks a mechanism for talking about cost, let alone rejecting coverage of expensive treatments that offer meager benefits?

headline.main: The Nation; Curbing the High Cost Of Health

docs.abstract: Michael M Weinstein article reviews issues of costs of high-tech medicine in age of managed care; photo (M)
